entry.title: Hotel Chelsea (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that during the late 20th century, residents of the Hotel Chelsea (pictured) could give the owner paintings instead of paying rent?

entry.title: John Hunter Thomas (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that insects not only destroyed the personal plant collection of John Hunter Thomas, but also bear his name?

entry.title: a new language (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that several dozen deported families spread across 2,000 kilometers (1,200 mi) from the swamps of Western Siberia to the rivers of Eastern Siberia and created a new language?

entry.title: Claude J. Crenshaw (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that with only three of the six guns in his P-51 Mustang working during a dogfight, Claude J. Crenshaw managed to shoot down four enemy aircraft?

entry.title: Hevenu shalom aleichem (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that after signing the Camp David Accords in 1978, Prime Minister Menachem Begin ended a speech with a desire to sing the peace song "Hevenu shalom aleichem" with the people of Israel?

entry.title: solar eclipse of September 10, 1923 (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that scientists traveled thousands of miles to observe the solar eclipse of September 10, 1923, from Santa Catalina Island, but saw only clouds?

entry.title: a TV station in Sitka, Alaska (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that until 1985, CBS programs on a TV station in Sitka, Alaska, were videotaped in Seattle and aired on a two-week delay?

entry.title: Julia Allison (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Julia Allison has been described as one of the first influencers?
